{{stack begin}} {{Taxobox | image= amanita fulva lowpx.jpg | image_width=235px | regnum = [[Fungus|Fungi]] | divisio = [[Basidiomycota]] | classis = [[Agaricomycetes]] | ordo = [[Agaricales]] | familia = [[Amanitaceae]] | genus = ''[[Amanita]]'' | species = '''''A. fulva''''' | binomial = ''Amanita fulva'' | binomial_authority = ([[Jacob Christian Schäffer|Schaeff.]]) [[Louis Secretan|Secr.]] | synonyms_ref = {{cite web |url=http://www.speciesfungorum.org/Names/SynSpecies.asp?RecordID=212682 |title=Synonymy: ''Amanita fulva'' |publisher=CAB International |work=Species Fungorum |accessdate=2011-10-07}} | synonyms = * ''Agaricus fulvus'' [[Jacob Christian Schäffer|Schäff.]]
* ''Amanita vaginata'' var. ''fulva'' ([[Elias Magnus Fries|Fr.]]) [[Claude Casimir Gillet|Gillet]] * ''Amanitopsis fulva'' (Fr.) [[Worthington George Smith|W.G. Sm.]] }} {{mycomorphbox | name = Amanita fulva | whichGills = free | capShape = umbonate | hymeniumType=gills | stipeCharacter=volva | ecologicalType=mycorrhizal | sporePrintColor=white | howEdible=edible }} {{stack end}} '''''Amanita fulva''''', commonly called the '''tawny grisette''', is a [[basidiomycete]] [[mushroom]] of the [[genus]] ''[[Amanita]]''. It is found frequently in deciduous and coniferous forests of [[Europe]], and possibly North America. ==Taxonomy and naming== ''Amanita fulva'' was first described by [[Jacob Christian Schäffer]] in 1774. Historically, both the tawny grisette and the grisette (''[[Amanita vaginata|A. vaginata]]'') were placed in the genus ''[[Amanitopsis]]'' due to their lack of a ring, unlike other ''[[Amanita]]'' species. However this distinction is now seen as insufficient to warrant a separate genus. Nowadays, ''A. fulva'' and similar ringless species of ''Amanita'' are placed in the section ''[[List of Amanita species#Section Vaginatae|Vaginatae]]'' ss according to the classification of [[Cornelis Bas|Bas]]. ==Description== {{multiple image | align = left | width = 100 | footer = Maturation of ''A. fulva'' in three stages - an emergent (far left), an immature (middle) and a mature specimen (right). Note the glistening brown caps, smooth white stems and brown-tinged volvas. | footer_background = | background color = | image1 = Amanita fulva - UK.JPG | alt1 = Emergent | caption1 = Emergent | image2 = Amanita fulva.jpg | alt2 = Immature | caption2 = Immature | image3 = Amanita fulva 060820w.jpg | alt3 = Mature | caption3 = Mature }} The [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] is orange-brown, paler towards the margin, and darker (even very dark brown) in the center, up to 10 cm in diameter. It develops an [[Umbo (mycology)|umbo]] when expanded, and has a strongly striated margin. Its surface is smooth, slightly sticky and slippery when moist and glistens; later it may dry.{{cite web |publisher=Rogers Plants Ltd | title=''Amanita fulva'' at Rogers Mushrooms. | url=http://www.rogersmushrooms.com/gallery/DisplayBlock~bid~5539.asp |accessdate=2011-10-07}} The [[Lamella (mycology)|gills]] are free, close, and broad. The [[Trama (mycology)|flesh]] is white to cream. The [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] or stipe is white and smooth or powdery, sometimes tinged with orange-brown and with very fine hairs. It is slender, ringless, hollow and quite fragile, tapering towards the top; up to 15 cm tall and 1–1.5 cm in thickness.{{cite web | url = http://www.first-nature.com/fungi/amanita-fulva.php | title = ''Amanita fulva'', Tawny Grisette, identification guide | publisher = First Nature |accessdate=2011-10-07}} The [[universal veil]] which initially encapsulates the fruiting body is torn and develops into a white, sack-like [[Volva (mycology)|volva]] with characteristic rusty-brown blemishes. The cap is usually free of volval remnants. Infrequently, roughly polygonal pieces of the veil may remain on the surface.{{cite web | url = http://www.amanitaceae.org/index.php?Amanita%20fulva | title = ''Amanita fulva''|work=Amanitaceae.org |accessdate=2016-08-05}} The spores are white, 9 × 12 [[µm]] or (9.0-) 10.0 - 12.5 (-19.3) x (8.2-) 9.3 - 12.0 (-15.5) µm in size, globose; [[nonamyloid]].Rodham E. Tulloss-Amanita fulva (Schaeff.) Fr. http://pluto.njcc.com/~ret/amanita/species/fulva.html {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060106193252/http://pluto.njcc.com/~ret/amanita/species/fulva.html |date=2006-01-06 }} ==Distribution and habitat== ''Amanita fulva'', distributed throughout Europe, occurs in a variety of forests. It is generally found with [[oak]] (''Quercus''), [[birch]] (''Betula''), [[spruce]] (''Picea''), [[pine]] (''Pinus''), [[chestnut]] (''Castanea'') and [[alder]] (''Alnus''), with which it forms [[mycorrhiza]]e. It is often found with birch in Scandinavia, while collections from southern Europe are usually from forests of oak, chestnut and pine.{{cite book | author = Fraiture A. | year = 1993 | title = Les Amanitopsis d'Europe | language = French | publisher = Jardin Botanique Nationale de Belgique | pages = 75–8 | isbn = 90-72619-09-9 | issn = 0775-9592}} It grows in acidic soils and fruits from summer to late autumn (May to November in the UK). It is a common to scarce fungus,{{cite book | author = Régis Courtecuisse and Bernard Duhem | year = 1995 | title = Mushrooms & Toadstools of Britain and Europe | publisher = Harper Collins | pages = 274–75 | isbn = 0-00-220025-2}} and is very common in Britain.{{cite book |author=Jordan M. |title=The Encyclopedia of Fungi of Britain and Europe |publisher=David & Charles |location=London |year=1995 |page=197 |isbn=0-7153-0129-2}}[http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?hl=en&sl=es&u=http://www.asturnatura.com/distribucion/amanita-fulva.html&prev=/search%3Fq%3DAmanita%2Bfulva%26start%3D70%26hl%3Den%26client%3Dfirefox-a%26sa%3DN%26rls%3Dorg.mozilla:en-US:official%26biw%3D1280%26bih%3D618%26prmdo%3D1%26prmd%3Di&rurl=translate.google.co.in&usg=ALkJrhiWz-zUvUBM1v8stnbJqRDnqCGq4w Amanita Fulva: Distribution and populations], asturnatura.com, translated from [http://www.asturnatura.com/distribucion/amanita-fulva.html the original] ''Amanita fulva'' is considered to be widely distributed in North America in deciduous and coniferous forests, although collections could possibly be of a different, yet undescribed species.Kuo, M. (2002, September). Amanita fulva. Retrieved from the MushroomExpert.Com Web site: http://www.mushroomexpert.com/amanita_fulva.html In addition, the name ''Amanita fulva'' has in the past been misapplied to other North American taxa, such as ''[[Amanita amerifulva|A. amerifulva]]'' and others. ==Edibility== ''Amanita fulva'' is one of the few good edible species in the genus ''[[Amanita]]''. Though this particular species is considered edible, it must be identified with care as other members of the genus ''Amanita'' are poisonous and some are deadly. For this reason, collection for consumption of ''A. fulva'' can be dangerous and is not recommended.{{cite book| first=Roger| last= Phillips| title=Mushrooms and Other Fungi of North America| year=2010| ISBN=978-1-55407-651-2| publisher=Firefly Books}} Some authors indicate the fungus is potentially toxic when raw, and is suitable for consumption only when cooked.{{cite book| first=Gérard| last= Houdou| title=Le grand livre des champignons| language=French | page=16 | year=2004 | ISBN=2-84494-270-9| publisher=Editions de Borée}}{{cite book| first=Wright| last= John| title=Mushrooms: River Cottage Handbook | page=68 | year=2007 | ISBN=0-7475-8932-1| publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing}} ==See also== *[[List of Amanita species|List of ''Amanita'' species]] ==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{Commons|Amanita fulva|Amanita fulva}} {{Amanitas}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q301792}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Amanita Fulva}} [[Category:Amanita|fulva]] [[Category:Edible fungi]] [[Category:Fungi of Europe]] [[Category:Fungi of North America]]
